elements.content: A novel cobalt­(II)-based metal–organic framework, Co–MB, was prepared by hydrothermal reaction of Co­(NO3)2·6H2O, 3,3′-methylene­diphthalic acid (H4mda), and 1,4-bis­(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)-benzene in sodium hydroxide aqueous solution and structurally characterized. It shows a high stability in water within the pH range from 2.2 to 11.6, which could be used as a highly selective and sensitive luminescent sensor for Ag­(I) detection in a luminescent enhancement manner, with LOD about 23 nM. Importantly, such stable Co–MB could also work as proton reduction catalyst for photodriven hydrogen production coupled with visible-light organic dyes as photosensitizer. The influence factors of hydrogen production including pH, TEA (triethylamine) contents, and kinds of organic dyes are studied in detail. Under optimal condition, the TON value was up to 5133 per cycle, and this Co–MB could also be reused at least 3 times.
elements.clean_text: A novel cobalt(II)-based metal-organic framework, Co-MB, was prepared by hydrothermal reaction of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O, 3,3'-methylenediphthalic acid (H4mda), and 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)-benzene in sodium hydroxide aqueous solution and structurally characterized. It shows a high stability in water within the pH range from 2.2 to 11.6, which could be used as a highly selective and sensitive luminescent sensor for Ag(I) detection in a luminescent enhancement manner, with LOD about 23 nM. Importantly, such stable Co-MB could also work as proton reduction catalyst for photodriven hydrogen production coupled with visible-light organic dyes as photosensitizer. The influence factors of hydrogen production including pH, TEA (triethylamine) contents, and kinds of organic dyes are studied in detail. Under optimal condition, the TON value was up to 5133 per cycle, and this Co-MB could also be reused at least 3 times.

elements.content: A novel cobalt­(II)-based metal−organic framework shows turn-on luminescence response to Ag­(I) and also works as proton reduction catalyst coupled with fluorescein for highly efficient visible-light-driven hydrogen evolution.
elements.clean_text: A novel cobalt(II)-based metal-organic framework shows turn-on luminescence response to Ag(I) and also works as proton reduction catalyst coupled with fluorescein for highly efficient visible-light-driven hydrogen evolution.

elements.content: Increasing environmental pollution problems has created an urgent demand for pollutant detection. Silver is one of the most demanding metals, and it has been widely applied in the imaging, photographic, and electronic industries. Due to good antibacterial properties of silver, sulfhydryl enzymes can be deactivated and carboxyl groups, imidazole, and amine of a variety of metabolites can be combined. Silver ions (Ag+) are also one of the most ubiquitous and perilous pollutants. Kidney damage, stomach distress, seizures can occur, the skin turns bluish-gray when excess silver ions are ingested, and this kind of argyria is irreversible. Just because that Ag+ can be bio-accumulated up to high concentration and has serious toxicity; thus, it is highly desirable to construct a selective and sensitive sensor for Ag+ quantification in aqueous solution for the ecological environment and human health.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Increasing environmental pollution problems has created an urgent demand for pollutant detection. Silver is one of the most demanding metals, and it has been widely applied in the imaging, photographic, and electronic industries. Due to good antibacterial properties of silver, sulfhydryl enzymes can be deactivated and carboxyl groups, imidazole, and amine of a variety of metabolites can be combined. Silver ions (Ag+) are also one of the most ubiquitous and perilous pollutants. Kidney damage, stomach distress, seizures can occur, the skin turns bluish-gray when excess silver ions are ingested, and this kind of argyria is irreversible. Just because that Ag+ can be bio-accumulated up to high concentration and has serious toxicity; thus, it is highly desirable to construct a selective and sensitive sensor for Ag+ quantification in aqueous solution for the ecological environment and human health.

elements.content: On the other hand, environmental security and depletion of traditional energy resources initiated the pursuit of renewable and clean power sources. The promising strategy is the photodriven water splitting to generate environmentally friendly hydrogen. In a typical photocatalytic hydrogen production experiment, platinum and other noble metals can be used as hydrogen production catalysts; however, further development and/or vast applications are precluded by their limited earth abundance and expensive cost. As attractive catalysts for this transformation, organometallic compounds have many advantages: (1) a variety of complexes can be prepared, (2) electronic properties (and hence catalyst activity) can be modulated through the easy synthesis, and (3) their mechanisms can be studied in detail. In recent years, earth-abundant transition metals, e.g., Ni, Co, and Fe, applied in several catalytic systems have been used for developing photogeneration of hydrogen. Some of them, particularly those that mimic the active sites of natural hydrogenases, have exhibited efficient hydrogen production from water. However, most of these systems are operated in homogeneous manners and the difficulty to reuse limited the large scale and practical applications. The design of new and efficient hydrogen evolution catalyst is still high desirable.
elements.clean_text: On the other hand, environmental security and depletion of traditional energy resources initiated the pursuit of renewable and clean power sources. The promising strategy is the photodriven water splitting to generate environmentally friendly hydrogen. In a typical photocatalytic hydrogen production experiment, platinum and other noble metals can be used as hydrogen production catalysts; however, further development and/or vast applications are precluded by their limited earth abundance and expensive cost. As attractive catalysts for this transformation, organometallic compounds have many advantages: (1) a variety of complexes can be prepared, (2) electronic properties (and hence catalyst activity) can be modulated through the easy synthesis, and (3) their mechanisms can be studied in detail. In recent years, earth-abundant transition metals, e.g., Ni, Co, and Fe, applied in several catalytic systems have been used for developing photogeneration of hydrogen. Some of them, particularly those that mimic the active sites of natural hydrogenases, have exhibited efficient hydrogen production from water. However, most of these systems are operated in homogeneous manners and the difficulty to reuse limited the large scale and practical applications. The design of new and efficient hydrogen evolution catalyst is still high desirable.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are a class of crystalline porous materials, assembled by the coordination of metal ions or clusters with organic linkers. MOFs as fluorescent sensors are more attractive and potential due to the inherent confinement effect within MOFs pores can enhance the host–guest interactions, facilitating the response expression with high sensitivity, fast response time, and easy visualization. However, there are only a handful of reports on MOF probes for Ag+ ions, which all utilized Ln3+-doped MOFs prepared by postsynthetic modifications; thus, developing a new strategy to construct effective MOF probes for identifying Ag+ anions still remains challenging. Meanwhile, in the case of several MOF characters such as large interfacial surface areas, short electron–hole diffusion lengths to the internal interfaces, and multiple routes for band gap engineering through compositional and structural control, MOFs also have received much more attention as photocatalysts for dyes effluents degradation, organic transformation, CO2 reduction, and hydrogen production. Herein, considering easy tunability of the metal nodes of MOFs, cobalt as the most versatile non-noble metal for developing synthetic oxygen and hydrogen evolution catalysts in the past decade was introduced into a new MOF Co–MB via the hydrothermal reaction of cobalt nitrate, 3,3′-methylenediphthalic acid (H4mda), and 1,4-bis­(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)-benzene (bib) in sodium hydroxide aqueous solution. Co–MB can act as a bifunctional material for luminescent detection of Ag­(I) and prompting photodriven hydrogen production as proton reduction catalyst.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are a class of crystalline porous materials, assembled by the coordination of metal ions or clusters with organic linkers. MOFs as fluorescent sensors are more attractive and potential due to the inherent confinement effect within MOFs pores can enhance the host-guest interactions, facilitating the response expression with high sensitivity, fast response time, and easy visualization. However, there are only a handful of reports on MOF probes for Ag+ ions, which all utilized Ln3+-doped MOFs prepared by postsynthetic modifications; thus, developing a new strategy to construct effective MOF probes for identifying Ag+ anions still remains challenging. Meanwhile, in the case of several MOF characters such as large interfacial surface areas, short electron-hole diffusion lengths to the internal interfaces, and multiple routes for band gap engineering through compositional and structural control, MOFs also have received much more attention as photocatalysts for dyes effluents degradation, organic transformation, CO2 reduction, and hydrogen production. Herein, considering easy tunability of the metal nodes of MOFs, cobalt as the most versatile non-noble metal for developing synthetic oxygen and hydrogen evolution catalysts in the past decade was introduced into a new MOF Co-MB via the hydrothermal reaction of cobalt nitrate, 3,3'-methylenediphthalic acid (H4mda), and 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)-benzene (bib) in sodium hydroxide aqueous solution. Co-MB can act as a bifunctional material for luminescent detection of Ag(I) and prompting photodriven hydrogen production as proton reduction catalyst.

elements.content: All reagents and solvents were of AR grade and used without further purification unless otherwise noted. The C, H, and N elemental analyses were determined on a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. A Rigaku D/max-2400 X-ray powder diffractometer (Japan) was used to check X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns of Co–MB using Cu–Kα (λ = 1.5405 Å) radiation. A Mettler-Toledo TGA/​SDTA­851 instrument was used to perform thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) at a 5 °C/min ramp rate in a nitrogen flow. The Co2+ contents before and after detection/catalysis were measured by an Inductively Coupled Plasma Spectrometer (PerkinElmer). A Bruker Optics TENSOR 27 FT-IR spectrophotometer was used to carry out FT-IR spectra using KBr pellets. An HP 8453 spectrometer was used to test solid ultraviolet–visible spectra. A Hitachi F-4600 was used to measure fluorescent spectra of the solution.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Methods and Measurements

All reagents and solvents were of AR grade and used without further purification unless otherwise noted. The C, H, and N elemental analyses were determined on a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. A Rigaku D/max-2400 X-ray powder diffractometer (Japan) was used to check X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns of Co-MB using Cu-Kα (λ = 1.5405 Å) radiation. A Mettler-Toledo TGA/SDTA851 instrument was used to perform thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) at a 5 °C/min ramp rate in a nitrogen flow. The Co2+ contents before and after detection/catalysis were measured by an Inductively Coupled Plasma Spectrometer (PerkinElmer). A Bruker Optics TENSOR 27 FT-IR spectrophotometer was used to carry out FT-IR spectra using KBr pellets. An HP 8453 spectrometer was used to test solid ultraviolet-visible spectra. A Hitachi F-4600 was used to measure fluorescent spectra of the solution.

elements.content: A mixture of 0.0287 g of Co­(NO3)2·6H2O, 0.0165 g of 3,3′-methylenediphthalic acid (H4mda), 0.0270 g of 1,4-bis­(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)-benzene (bib) (its chemical structure is shown in Figure S1 in the Supporting Information (SI)), and 0.0085 g of sodium hydroxide was dissolved in water (8 mL) in a screw capped vial. The mixture was then placed in an oven at 120 °C for 3 days. Purple crystals with a block shape were obtained after filtration. Yield: 70%. Anal. Calc. for C45H42­N8O11Co2: C 54.66, H 4.28, N 11.33%; Found: C 54.58, H 4.31, N 11.32%. CCDC: 1845081 (its crystal data are shown in Table S1 in the SI).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Co-MB

A mixture of 0.0287 g of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O, 0.0165 g of 3,3'-methylenediphthalic acid (H4mda), 0.0270 g of 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)-benzene (bib) (its chemical structure is shown in Figure S1 in the Supporting Information (SI)), and 0.0085 g of sodium hydroxide was dissolved in water (8 mL) in a screw capped vial. The mixture was then placed in an oven at 120 °C for 3 days. Purple crystals with a block shape were obtained after filtration. Yield: 70%. Anal. Calc. for C45H42N8O11Co2: C 54.66, H 4.28, N 11.33%; Found: C 54.58, H 4.31, N 11.32%. CCDC: 1845081 (its crystal data are shown in Table S1 in the SI).

elements.content: Fluorescence measurements of the Co–MB suspension were carried out in a 1 cm quartz cuvette; slit widths of both the emission and excitation were 2.5 nm. For metal ions detection, the solutions of related metal ions with 2.0 × 10–2 M concentration were prepared in water. And the relative fluorescence intensity is adopted through normalizing the fluorescence intensity to eliminate the influence of initial fluorescence on the measurement.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence Spectra Detection

Fluorescence measurements of the Co-MB suspension were carried out in a 1 cm quartz cuvette; slit widths of both the emission and excitation were 2.5 nm. For metal ions detection, the solutions of related metal ions with 2.0 × 10-2 M concentration were prepared in water. And the relative fluorescence intensity is adopted through normalizing the fluorescence intensity to eliminate the influence of initial fluorescence on the measurement.

elements.content: Each sample was placed in a 10 mL flask containing 5 mL of 1:1 ethanol and water mixture for photoinduced hydrogen evolution. Typically, the samples were composed of 0.1 mM Co–MB, 1.5 mM Eosin Y, and 5% (v/v) sacrificial electron donor (TEA). First, the flask was sealed up, then degassed by bubbling nitrogen for 30 min at r.t., and protected from light during this process. After that, the samples were irradiated by a 500 W xenon lamp equipped with a UV cutoff filter (λ ≥ 420 nm); the reaction temperature was 293 K by using a water filter to absorb heat. The produced hydrogen was determined through a GC 7890T instrument with thermal conductivity detector and a molecular sieve column (0.6 m × 3 mm) of 5 Å, and carrier gas adopted nitrogen. The external standard method was used to determine the amount of generated hydrogen. In this process of calculating the volume of hydrogen gas, we did not measure H2 in the resulting solution and neglected the slight effect of the generated hydrogen on the flask pressure.
elements.clean_text:
Photoinduced Hydrogen Production

Each sample was placed in a 10 mL flask containing 5 mL of 1:1 ethanol and water mixture for photoinduced hydrogen evolution. Typically, the samples were composed of 0.1 mM Co-MB, 1.5 mM Eosin Y, and 5% (v/v) sacrificial electron donor (TEA). First, the flask was sealed up, then degassed by bubbling nitrogen for 30 min at r.t., and protected from light during this process. After that, the samples were irradiated by a 500 W xenon lamp equipped with a UV cutoff filter (λ ≥ 420 nm); the reaction temperature was 293 K by using a water filter to absorb heat. The produced hydrogen was determined through a GC 7890T instrument with thermal conductivity detector and a molecular sieve column (0.6 m × 3 mm) of 5 Å, and carrier gas adopted nitrogen. The external standard method was used to determine the amount of generated hydrogen. In this process of calculating the volume of hydrogen gas, we did not measure H2 in the resulting solution and neglected the slight effect of the generated hydrogen on the flask pressure.

elements.content: A novel three-dimensional metal–organic skeleton complex, Co–MB ({[Co2­(C17H8­O8)­(C14H14­N4)2]·3H2O} n ), was obtained by a hydrothermal reaction of 3,3′-methylene­diphthalic acid (H4mda), 1,4-bis­(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)-benzene (bib), and Co­(NO3)2·6H2O in sodium hydroxide aqueous solution. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that Co–MB crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅ and is made up of two crystallographically independent CoII atoms, one mda4– ligand, two different types of bib ligands, and three free water molecules per asymmetric unit. As shown in a, Co1 and Co2 centers both adopt distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry with two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two different mda4– anions and two nitrogen atoms from two different bib ligands. The Co–O bond lengths range from 1.953(2) to 1.960(2) Å, the Co–N distances are within the range of 1.996(2)–2.031(3) Å. The mda4– ligands exhibit μ4 monodentate modes to bridge four Co­(II) ions to form a 1D infinite chain [Co4­(mda)]∞ (b and Figure S2 in the SI). These 1D chains are interconnected together by two different types of bib ligands to generate a 2D layer. As for one type of bib ligands (c: violet), the dihedral angles 63.01°, 65.24° of the terminal imidazole groups corresponding to the phenyl ring plane were observed, and 52.16° of twist occurred in two pairs of imidazole groups, which joins the Co2+ centers from adjacent chains with a Co1···Co2 separation of 14.02 Å.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Description

A novel three-dimensional metal-organic skeleton complex, Co-MB ({[Co2(C17H8O8)(C14H14N4)2]⋅3H2O} n ), was obtained by a hydrothermal reaction of 3,3'-methylenediphthalic acid (H4mda), 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)-benzene (bib), and Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O in sodium hydroxide aqueous solution. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that Co-MB crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅ and is made up of two crystallographically independent CoII atoms, one mda4- ligand, two different types of bib ligands, and three free water molecules per asymmetric unit. As shown in a, Co1 and Co2 centers both adopt distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry with two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two different mda4- anions and two nitrogen atoms from two different bib ligands. The Co-O bond lengths range from 1.953(2) to 1.960(2) Å, the Co-N distances are within the range of 1.996(2)-2.031(3) Å. The mda4- ligands exhibit μ4 monodentate modes to bridge four Co(II) ions to form a 1D infinite chain [Co4(mda)]∞ (b and Figure S2 in the SI). These 1D chains are interconnected together by two different types of bib ligands to generate a 2D layer. As for one type of bib ligands (c: violet), the dihedral angles 63.01°, 65.24° of the terminal imidazole groups corresponding to the phenyl ring plane were observed, and 52.16° of twist occurred in two pairs of imidazole groups, which joins the Co2+ centers from adjacent chains with a Co1⋅⋅⋅Co2 separation of 14.02 Å.

elements.content: (a) The coordination geometry of Co­(II) centers in Co–MB. (b) 1D infinite chain [Co4(mda)]∞ formed by Co­(II) ions and mda4– ligands. (c) A double-helical chain formed by Co2+ ions and two types of bib ligands marked in violet and blue, respectively. (d) The crystal structure of Co–MB with the ellipsoid channels along b direction. (e) (4, 2)-connected topology of Co–MB.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) The coordination geometry of Co(II) centers in Co-MB. (b) 1D infinite chain [Co4(mda)]∞ formed by Co(II) ions and mda4- ligands. (c) A double-helical chain formed by Co2+ ions and two types of bib ligands marked in violet and blue, respectively. (d) The crystal structure of Co-MB with the ellipsoid channels along b direction. (e) (4, 2)-connected topology of Co-MB.

elements.content: In the case of the other type of bib ligands (c: blue), their terminal imidazole groups have the dihedral angles of 79.96°, 82.28°, respectively, with respect to the linked phenyl ring plane and the torsion angle of 17.76° to each other, bridging Co1 and Co2 from another adjacent chain with a distance of 12.01 Å. Two types of bib ligands are connected with each other through Co2+ ions to produce a double-helical chain with opposite screw direction along the a direction, in which there exist π···π interactions (distance 3.25 Å) between imidazole rings of two types of bib ligands (c). Topologically, given CoII and mda4– as four-connected nodes, Co–MB can be simplified to be (4, 2)-connected topology with Schläfli symbol (4;64;8)2­(42;63;8), which is seldom reported in literature (e). The layers are further packed along the b-axis into a three-dimensional (3D) framework through C–H···π interaction (distance 2.98 Å) between the hydrogen atom of imidazole and phenyl ring of mda4– ligand belonging to neighboring layers. Elliptical channels accommodated by the lattice water molecules can be viewed with cross sections of 9.8 × 7.9 Å2 along the a axis, which is consistent with 11.2% of solvent-accessible volume per the unit cell calculated by the PLATON program (d). TGA data of Co–MB displayed a weight loss of 5.51% with temperatures of 26–270 °C, which is in accord that this structure loses three water molecules (calculated as 5.46%) and keeps stable until 380 °C (SI, Figure S3). The Co–MB with suitable channels allows ingress and egress of metal cations, driving the relative sensing and catalysis applications.
elements.clean_text: In the case of the other type of bib ligands (c: blue), their terminal imidazole groups have the dihedral angles of 79.96°, 82.28°, respectively, with respect to the linked phenyl ring plane and the torsion angle of 17.76° to each other, bridging Co1 and Co2 from another adjacent chain with a distance of 12.01 Å. Two types of bib ligands are connected with each other through Co2+ ions to produce a double-helical chain with opposite screw direction along the a direction, in which there exist π⋅⋅⋅π interactions (distance 3.25 Å) between imidazole rings of two types of bib ligands (c). Topologically, given CoII and mda4- as four-connected nodes, Co-MB can be simplified to be (4, 2)-connected topology with Schläfli symbol (4;64;8)2(42;63;8), which is seldom reported in literature (e). The layers are further packed along the b-axis into a three-dimensional (3D) framework through C-H⋅⋅⋅π interaction (distance 2.98 Å) between the hydrogen atom of imidazole and phenyl ring of mda4- ligand belonging to neighboring layers. Elliptical channels accommodated by the lattice water molecules can be viewed with cross sections of 9.8 × 7.9 Å2 along the a axis, which is consistent with 11.2% of solvent-accessible volume per the unit cell calculated by the PLATON program (d). TGA data of Co-MB displayed a weight loss of 5.51% with temperatures of 26-270 °C, which is in accord that this structure loses three water molecules (calculated as 5.46%) and keeps stable until 380 °C (SI, Figure S3). The Co-MB with suitable channels allows ingress and egress of metal cations, driving the relative sensing and catalysis applications.

elements.content: Solid state UV–vis absorption spectra of Co–MB displayed an intense absorption band centered at 325 nm, which was attributed to the π–π* transition of the 3,3′-methylene­diphthalic acid (Figure S4 in the SI)). Upon excitation at 325 nm, the Co–MB suspension in aqueous solution revealed an emission at 425 nm, which could be ascribed to the intraligand charge transfer (ILCT) as the neutral 3,3′-methylene­diphthalic acid ligand also exhibited the similar emission (Figure S5 in the SI). Considering abundant nitrogen sites in the structure of Co–MB, Co–MB has potential coordination sites for metal ions. In this regard, the sensing properties of Co–MB for metal ions were investigated. The fluorescence responses of Co–MB water standard emulsion toward some common metal ions containing K+, Na+, Li+, Ba2+, Ca2+, Mg2+, Sr2+, Co2+, Zn2+, Cu2+, Fe2+, Cd2+, Hg2+, Mn2+, Ni2+, Pb2+, and Ag+ were tested (b). Fluorescence spectra of Co–MB displayed almost no significant changes when there existed Mn2+, Ca2+, K+, Na+, Li+, Cd2+, Fe2+, Mg2+, and Sr2+, while Hg2+, Co2+, Pb2+, Ba2+, and Cu2+ just led to a slight fluorescence quenching and Zn2+, Ni2+ just caused a slight fluorescence increase (max. 8.6%) (Figure S6 in the SI). Compared with these metal ions mentioned above, only addition of Ag+ ions (0.17 mM) to Co–MB (60 μM) water solution caused ca. 2.8-fold increase in the fluorescence intensity (a). Further competition experiments revealed that 1 equiv of other metal ions did not affect the Ag+-induced luminescence enhancement (b). Moveover, even Hg2+, Co2+, Pb2+, and Cu2+ did not interfere with the Ag+-induced fluorescence enhancement, indicating that Co–MB had a remarkable selectivity for Ag+.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescent Properties and Detection of Ag(I)

Solid state UV-vis absorption spectra of Co-MB displayed an intense absorption band centered at 325 nm, which was attributed to the π-π* transition of the 3,3'-methylenediphthalic acid (Figure S4 in the SI)). Upon excitation at 325 nm, the Co-MB suspension in aqueous solution revealed an emission at 425 nm, which could be ascribed to the intraligand charge transfer (ILCT) as the neutral 3,3'-methylenediphthalic acid ligand also exhibited the similar emission (Figure S5 in the SI). Considering abundant nitrogen sites in the structure of Co-MB, Co-MB has potential coordination sites for metal ions. In this regard, the sensing properties of Co-MB for metal ions were investigated. The fluorescence responses of Co-MB water standard emulsion toward some common metal ions containing K+, Na+, Li+, Ba2+, Ca2+, Mg2+, Sr2+, Co2+, Zn2+, Cu2+, Fe2+, Cd2+, Hg2+, Mn2+, Ni2+, Pb2+, and Ag+ were tested (b). Fluorescence spectra of Co-MB displayed almost no significant changes when there existed Mn2+, Ca2+, K+, Na+, Li+, Cd2+, Fe2+, Mg2+, and Sr2+, while Hg2+, Co2+, Pb2+, Ba2+, and Cu2+ just led to a slight fluorescence quenching and Zn2+, Ni2+ just caused a slight fluorescence increase (max. 8.6%) (Figure S6 in the SI). Compared with these metal ions mentioned above, only addition of Ag+ ions (0.17 mM) to Co-MB (60 μM) water solution caused ca. 2.8-fold increase in the fluorescence intensity (a). Further competition experiments revealed that 1 equiv of other metal ions did not affect the Ag+-induced luminescence enhancement (b). Moveover, even Hg2+, Co2+, Pb2+, and Cu2+ did not interfere with the Ag+-induced fluorescence enhancement, indicating that Co-MB had a remarkable selectivity for Ag+.

elements.content: (a) Fluorescence spectra of Co–MB aqueous suspension (60 μM) upon adding Ag+ up to 0.17 mM. (b) The selectivity and competition experiments of Co–MB (60 μM) in H2O solution for various cations. The red bars stand for the fluorescence intensities of Co–MB when there existed 0.17 mM of the metal ions. The green ones stand for the fluorescence change upon the subsequent adding 0.17 mM of Ag+ to the above solution.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Fluorescence spectra of Co-MB aqueous suspension (60 μM) upon adding Ag+ up to 0.17 mM. (b) The selectivity and competition experiments of Co-MB (60 μM) in H2O solution for various cations. The red bars stand for the fluorescence intensities of Co-MB when there existed 0.17 mM of the metal ions. The green ones stand for the fluorescence change upon the subsequent adding 0.17 mM of Ag+ to the above solution.

elements.content: To further understand the luminescence response of Co–MB toward Ag+ ions, the luminescence titrations of adding Ag+ ions to Co–MB water suspension were conducted. It can be found the fluorescence emission intensity at 425 nm gradually increases from its initial value accompanied by the addition of Ag+ ions. According to the result of titrating experiment, a linearly proportional curve is then fitted between the normalized emission intensity [the original fluorescent intensity (I 0 = 142.3) is defined as 1.0] and the concentrations of Ag+ in the region of 0–3.4 × 10–5 M, suggesting that Co–MB also has a great potential to quantitatively determine Ag+. The limit of detection for Ag+ is about 23 nM according to the 3δ IUPAC criteria, which is far lower than the maximum permitted Ag+ level (1.85 μM) in the 2012 Edition of the Drinking Water Standards and Health Advisories set by the U.S.A. The low detection limit for Ag+ demonstrated that Co–MB was a highly sensitive sensor for Ag+ detection.
elements.clean_text: To further understand the luminescence response of Co-MB toward Ag+ ions, the luminescence titrations of adding Ag+ ions to Co-MB water suspension were conducted. It can be found the fluorescence emission intensity at 425 nm gradually increases from its initial value accompanied by the addition of Ag+ ions. According to the result of titrating experiment, a linearly proportional curve is then fitted between the normalized emission intensity [the original fluorescent intensity (I 0 = 142.3) is defined as 1.0] and the concentrations of Ag+ in the region of 0-3.4 × 10-5 M, suggesting that Co-MB also has a great potential to quantitatively determine Ag+. The limit of detection for Ag+ is about 23 nM according to the 3δ IUPAC criteria, which is far lower than the maximum permitted Ag+ level (1.85 μM) in the 2012 Edition of the Drinking Water Standards and Health Advisories set by the U.S.A. The low detection limit for Ag+ demonstrated that Co-MB was a highly sensitive sensor for Ag+ detection.

elements.content: With regards to the shape of the Co–MB framework and the orientation of the nitrogen atoms toward the cavity, there is the possibility to chelate the metal ions through nitrogen atoms from bib ligands presented in the structure (a). To further investigate the possible mechanism of Ag+ detection on Co–MB, the powder X-ray powder diffraction (PXRD) and inductively coupled plasma (ICP) measurements were performed to monitor the structure changes during Ag+ sensing process. As shown in Figure S7, the comparative powder XRD data of the Co–MB bulk sample after immersing in Ag+ solution for 5 h showed that a few new peaks (marked with asterisks) come out besides those patterns of the original Co–MB were preserved, suggesting that the basic framework is not impacted by the introduction of Ag+. Meanwhile, ICP measurements showed there was negligible Co2+ content detected in the filtrate, thus also excluding that the title compound was dissolved and Co2+ in the lattice was exchanged by Ag+. The FT-IR spectra of the dried specimens were compared before and after the adsorption of the metallic species. (b) The peak at 1373 cm–1, which is related to aromatic amines, has got a significant change after the adsorption process, and a new band appears at 1633 cm–1, which is assignable to the vibration of nitrogen atoms that formed a coordination bond with a metal ions. The peak at 1381 cm–1 is a characteristic peak for the stretching vibration of NO2 in the NO3 – ions. Hence, NO3 – ions were on the surface of Co–MB to balance the electrical charges of the adsorbed silver ions. All changes occurred after Ag+ adsorption by Co–MB can be attributed to the formation of a chemical bond between the nitrogen atom and Ag+.
elements.clean_text: With regards to the shape of the Co-MB framework and the orientation of the nitrogen atoms toward the cavity, there is the possibility to chelate the metal ions through nitrogen atoms from bib ligands presented in the structure (a). To further investigate the possible mechanism of Ag+ detection on Co-MB, the powder X-ray powder diffraction (PXRD) and inductively coupled plasma (ICP) measurements were performed to monitor the structure changes during Ag+ sensing process. As shown in Figure S7, the comparative powder XRD data of the Co-MB bulk sample after immersing in Ag+ solution for 5 h showed that a few new peaks (marked with asterisks) come out besides those patterns of the original Co-MB were preserved, suggesting that the basic framework is not impacted by the introduction of Ag+. Meanwhile, ICP measurements showed there was negligible Co2+ content detected in the filtrate, thus also excluding that the title compound was dissolved and Co2+ in the lattice was exchanged by Ag+. The FT-IR spectra of the dried specimens were compared before and after the adsorption of the metallic species. (b) The peak at 1373 cm-1, which is related to aromatic amines, has got a significant change after the adsorption process, and a new band appears at 1633 cm-1, which is assignable to the vibration of nitrogen atoms that formed a coordination bond with a metal ions. The peak at 1381 cm-1 is a characteristic peak for the stretching vibration of NO2 in the NO3 - ions. Hence, NO3 - ions were on the surface of Co-MB to balance the electrical charges of the adsorbed silver ions. All changes occurred after Ag+ adsorption by Co-MB can be attributed to the formation of a chemical bond between the nitrogen atom and Ag+.

elements.content: It is a key transformation for water splitting via artificial photosynthesis (AP) to converse solar energy to stored chemical potential in the form of fuel and oxidizer. As we all know, photocatalytic water splitting to hydrogen systems are typically composed of a photosensitizer (PS), catalyst, and sacrificial electron donor. Metal-free organic dyes have attracted wide attention as PS owing to low cost, the easy handling, and tunable structures, fulfilling the basic principle of green chemistry. Therefore, we will next explore the visible-light photocatalytic hydrogen evolution via choosing Eosin Y as photosensitizer, our MOF Co–MB as catalyst, and TEA as the sacrificial electron donor.
elements.clean_text:
Co-MB as Proton Reduction Catalyst for Hydrogen Production

It is a key transformation for water splitting via artificial photosynthesis (AP) to converse solar energy to stored chemical potential in the form of fuel and oxidizer. As we all know, photocatalytic water splitting to hydrogen systems are typically composed of a photosensitizer (PS), catalyst, and sacrificial electron donor. Metal-free organic dyes have attracted wide attention as PS owing to low cost, the easy handling, and tunable structures, fulfilling the basic principle of green chemistry. Therefore, we will next explore the visible-light photocatalytic hydrogen evolution via choosing Eosin Y as photosensitizer, our MOF Co-MB as catalyst, and TEA as the sacrificial electron donor.

elements.content: First, the structure stability of Co–MB was examined via powder XRD measurements when immersed in water with the pH changes in the range of 2.2–11.6; the results exhibited the framework was unaffected by the harsh pH changes (Figure S8 in the SI). Next, the pH effect on H2 evolution was tested by using Eosin Y and Co–MB with the concentration of 1.5 mM and 0.1 mM, respectively, with 5% (v/v) electron donor (TEA) in CH3CH2­OH/​H2O (1:1) over 3 h irradiation at room temperature (a). Diluted hydrochloric acid will be dropwise added to adjust the pH value of the solution. The maximal turnover number value (TON) of H2 production was obtained at pH = 10, and a more acidic or more basic medium led to a sharp decrease. It is because that TEA may be protonated to a considerable extent when pH value was decreased, while the reduced cobalt catalyst will be not favorable to be protonated to produce the cobalt hydride species when pH value was increased up to 10, which is an accredited intermediate at the metal center of a molecular catalyst for proton reduction to hydrogen. Such pH dependence in H2 photosynthesis is commonly seen in many H2 evolution systems. The influence of TEA content on H2 evolution was discussed by changing the content of TEA in the condition that the amount of Co–MB, Eosin Y and the pH value of the system were first fixed as 0.1 mM, 1.5 mM, and 10.0, respectively. As shown in b, the maximal value of turnover number for H2 production was obtained at TEA = 5% (v/v). With an increase in the concentration of TEA from 5% to 10% or a decrease until 1%, the TON based on Co–MB was reduced from 783 to 321 or 218, respectively, in 3 h irradiation.
elements.clean_text: First, the structure stability of Co-MB was examined via powder XRD measurements when immersed in water with the pH changes in the range of 2.2-11.6; the results exhibited the framework was unaffected by the harsh pH changes (Figure S8 in the SI). Next, the pH effect on H2 evolution was tested by using Eosin Y and Co-MB with the concentration of 1.5 mM and 0.1 mM, respectively, with 5% (v/v) electron donor (TEA) in CH3CH2OH/H2O (1:1) over 3 h irradiation at room temperature (a). Diluted hydrochloric acid will be dropwise added to adjust the pH value of the solution. The maximal turnover number value (TON) of H2 production was obtained at pH = 10, and a more acidic or more basic medium led to a sharp decrease. It is because that TEA may be protonated to a considerable extent when pH value was decreased, while the reduced cobalt catalyst will be not favorable to be protonated to produce the cobalt hydride species when pH value was increased up to 10, which is an accredited intermediate at the metal center of a molecular catalyst for proton reduction to hydrogen. Such pH dependence in H2 photosynthesis is commonly seen in many H2 evolution systems. The influence of TEA content on H2 evolution was discussed by changing the content of TEA in the condition that the amount of Co-MB, Eosin Y and the pH value of the system were first fixed as 0.1 mM, 1.5 mM, and 10.0, respectively. As shown in b, the maximal value of turnover number for H2 production was obtained at TEA = 5% (v/v). With an increase in the concentration of TEA from 5% to 10% or a decrease until 1%, the TON based on Co-MB was reduced from 783 to 321 or 218, respectively, in 3 h irradiation.

elements.content: (a) Influence of the pH on photoinduced hydrogen production from the system comprising Eosin Y and Co–MB in the concentration of 1.5 mM and 0.1 mM, in 5% TEA (v/v) EtOH/H2O (1:1) over 3 h irradiation. (b) Influence of the TEA on hydrogen production from the system comprising Eosin Y and Co–MB in the concentration of 1.5 mM and 0.1 mM, in pH = 10 EtOH/H2O (1:1) over 3 h irradiation. (c) Hydrogen generation from Fl or EY solution, containing 0.1 mM Co–MB in EtOH/H2O. The conditions are as follows: pH = 10 EtOH/H2O solution with 5% TEA (v/v); irradiated with 500 W Xe lamps.

(b) Influence of the TEA on hydrogen production from the system comprising Eosin Y and Co-MB in the concentration of 1.5 mM and 0.1 mM, in pH = 10 EtOH/H2O (1:1) over 3 h irradiation. (c) Hydrogen generation from Fl or EY solution, containing 0.1 mM Co-MB in EtOH/H2O. The conditions are as follows: pH = 10 EtOH/H2O solution with 5% TEA (v/v); irradiated with 500 W Xe lamps.

elements.content: When a suspension containing Co–MB and Eosin Y with the concentration of 0.1 mM and 1.5 mM, respectively, 5% TEA (v/v), in a 1:1 mixed solution of water and ethanol with pH value of 10 was irradiated, there was approximately 311 mol of hydrogen per mole of catalyst per hour for the initial turnover frequency (TOF) and approximately 1050 for the highest hydrogen evolution TON based on catalyst Co–MB (c). Control experiments demonstrated that it was essential for all three components of the system for photodriven H2 generation; no appreciable amounts of hydrogen were observed when any of them were absent. Importantly, the artificial system could not perform well without light.
elements.clean_text: When a suspension containing Co-MB and Eosin Y with the concentration of 0.1 mM and 1.5 mM, respectively, 5% TEA (v/v), in a 1:1 mixed solution of water and ethanol with pH value of 10 was irradiated, there was approximately 311 mol of hydrogen per mole of catalyst per hour for the initial turnover frequency (TOF) and approximately 1050 for the highest hydrogen evolution TON based on catalyst Co-MB (c). Control experiments demonstrated that it was essential for all three components of the system for photodriven H2 generation; no appreciable amounts of hydrogen were observed when any of them were absent. Importantly, the artificial system could not perform well without light.

elements.content: Since Co–MB could work as a superior proton reduction catalyst for prompting hydrogen production, this strategy could be easily expanded, such as we can adjust the kinds of organic dyes used conveniently. Herein, in the optimized condition afforded from Eosin Y as photosensitizers, the commonly used other visible-light xanthene dyes, such as Fl (fluorescein), DCF (2′,7′-dichloro­fluorescein), and RB (Rose Bengal), were selected as photosensitizers and coupled with Co–MB for H2 production was carried out (a).
elements.clean_text: Since Co-MB could work as a superior proton reduction catalyst for prompting hydrogen production, this strategy could be easily expanded, such as we can adjust the kinds of organic dyes used conveniently. Herein, in the optimized condition afforded from Eosin Y as photosensitizers, the commonly used other visible-light xanthene dyes, such as Fl (fluorescein), DCF (2',7'-dichlorofluorescein), and RB (Rose Bengal), were selected as photosensitizers and coupled with Co-MB for H2 production was carried out (a).

elements.content: (a) The chemical structure of selected organic dyes. (b) H2 production upon the irradiation of the system of TEA (5.0%, v/v), Co–MB (0.1 mM), and 1.5 mM different fluorescein derivatives: Fluorescein (Fl), 2′,7′-dichlorofluorescein (DFl), Eosin Y (EY), and Rose Bengal (RB), respectively. (c) Powder XRD patterns of simulated and as-synthesized Co–MB, and Co–MB after 3 cycles of catalysis. (d) H2 production of the Co–MB system when fresh solutions of TEA (5%, v/v) and Fl (1.5 mM) every 15 h were added as time approaches.
elements.clean_text: 5  (a) The chemical structure of selected organic dyes. (b) H2 production upon the irradiation of the system of TEA (5.0%, v/v), Co-MB (0.1 mM), and 1.5 mM different fluorescein derivatives: Fluorescein (Fl), 2',7'-dichlorofluorescein (DFl), Eosin Y (EY), and Rose Bengal (RB), respectively. (c) Powder XRD patterns of simulated and as-synthesized Co-MB, and Co-MB after 3 cycles of catalysis. (d) H2 production of the Co-MB system when fresh solutions of TEA (5%, v/v) and Fl (1.5 mM) every 15 h were added as time approaches.

elements.content: Irradiation of a TEA (5%, v/v), CH3CH2OH/H2O = 1:1, pH = 10 solution with xanthene dyes and Co–MB in the fixed concentration of 1.5 mM and 0.1 mM, respectively, the results for H2 production in 15 h are shown in b. There is a significant difference in the hydrogen production efficiency; the TON values were 381 for RB, 1050 for EY, 2712 for DCF, and 5131 for Fl, respectively, and despite these dyes all exhibit absorption in the visible-light region (b). Usually, the presence of heavy atoms such as Br or I enhances the efficiency of the long-lived triplet excited state and gives greater amount of H2 produced. The fact that fluorescein itself provides the highest activity among the photosensitizers DCF, EY, and RB suggests that the electronic effects do not dominate the photosynthetic system. Alternatively, the size of the photosensitizers and the proper supramolecular weak interaction may be potentially the major factor controling the activity of the light-driven H2 evolution. And such TON value (5131) is much higher than the highest values reported for the related homogeneous Co-based systems by using RB as photosensitizer.
elements.clean_text: Irradiation of a TEA (5%, v/v), CH3CH2OH/H2O = 1:1, pH = 10 solution with xanthene dyes and Co-MB in the fixed concentration of 1.5 mM and 0.1 mM, respectively, the results for H2 production in 15 h are shown in b. There is a significant difference in the hydrogen production efficiency; the TON values were 381 for RB, 1050 for EY, 2712 for DCF, and 5131 for Fl, respectively, and despite these dyes all exhibit absorption in the visible-light region (b). Usually, the presence of heavy atoms such as Br or I enhances the efficiency of the long-lived triplet excited state and gives greater amount of H2 produced. The fact that fluorescein itself provides the highest activity among the photosensitizers DCF, EY, and RB suggests that the electronic effects do not dominate the photosynthetic system. Alternatively, the size of the photosensitizers and the proper supramolecular weak interaction may be potentially the major factor controling the activity of the light-driven H2 evolution. And such TON value (5131) is much higher than the highest values reported for the related homogeneous Co-based systems by using RB as photosensitizer.

elements.content: Considering the usage in industrial applications, recyclability is an essential requirement of any catalyst. The Co–MB materials collected from the photocatalytic system via centrifugation were reapplied to hydrogen evolution in a fresh solution with Fl as photosensitizer since it showed the best efficiency for H2 production. These time-course experiments gave a total TON value of 14 945 per mole of catalyst Co–MB after 3 times of catalysis (45 h). It is worth noting that such a high TON value (>12 000) indicated that Co–MB has the broad practical application prospect for photodriven hydrogen production in the chemical industry. Meanwhile, PXRD measurements of Co–MB filtrated from the catalytic reaction were performed, evidencing their framework was maintained and Co–MB had the excellent stability after 3 cycles. Furthermore, ICP-MS analysis of the supernatant after the final reaction found only trace of the Co leaching into the solution during the reaction.
elements.clean_text: Considering the usage in industrial applications, recyclability is an essential requirement of any catalyst. The Co-MB materials collected from the photocatalytic system via centrifugation were reapplied to hydrogen evolution in a fresh solution with Fl as photosensitizer since it showed the best efficiency for H2 production. These time-course experiments gave a total TON value of 14945 per mole of catalyst Co-MB after 3 times of catalysis (45 h). It is worth noting that such a high TON value (>12000) indicated that Co-MB has the broad practical application prospect for photodriven hydrogen production in the chemical industry. Meanwhile, PXRD measurements of Co-MB filtrated from the catalytic reaction were performed, evidencing their framework was maintained and Co-MB had the excellent stability after 3 cycles. Furthermore, ICP-MS analysis of the supernatant after the final reaction found only trace of the Co leaching into the solution during the reaction.

elements.content: In conclusion, we have successfully targeted a novel nitrogen-enriched MOF Co–MB. It exhibits high chemical stability in pH ranged from 2.2 to 11.6 and is also a good turn-on luminescent chemosensor for Ag+ even in the presence of many other metal ions. The calculated detection limit is only 23 nM, far lower than the maximum permitted Ag+ level (1.85 μM) in the 2012 Edition of the Drinking Water Standards and Health Advisories set by the U.S.A. With the redox activity of the Co­(II) nodes, Co–MB could also act as proton reduction catalyst coupled with fluorescein as photosensitizers for highly efficient visual-light-driven hydrogen evolution. This MOF displays the highest activity with a turnover number reaching 14 945 per mole of Co–MB after 3 cycles (45 h) of repeated reactions. The current strategy not only can enrich the kinds of cobalt­(II)-based catalyst but also can be popularized easily.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, we have successfully targeted a novel nitrogen-enriched MOF Co-MB. It exhibits high chemical stability in pH ranged from 2.2 to 11.6 and is also a good turn-on luminescent chemosensor for Ag+ even in the presence of many other metal ions. The calculated detection limit is only 23 nM, far lower than the maximum permitted Ag+ level (1.85 μM) in the 2012 Edition of the Drinking Water Standards and Health Advisories set by the U.S.A. With the redox activity of the Co(II) nodes, Co-MB could also act as proton reduction catalyst coupled with fluorescein as photosensitizers for highly efficient visual-light-driven hydrogen evolution. This MOF displays the highest activity with a turnover number reaching 14945 per mole of Co-MB after 3 cycles (45 h) of repeated reactions. The current strategy not only can enrich the kinds of cobalt(II)-based catalyst but also can be popularized easily.

cln_elements.content: A mixture of 0.0287 g of Co­(NO3)2·6H2O, 0.0165 g of 3,3′-methylenediphthalic acid (H4mda), 0.0270 g of 1,4-bis­(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)-benzene (bib) (its chemical structure is shown in Figure S1 in the Supporting Information (SI)), and 0.0085 g of sodium hydroxide was dissolved in water (8 mL) in a screw capped vial. The mixture was then placed in an oven at 120 °C for 3 days. Purple crystals with a block shape were obtained after filtration. Yield: 70%. Anal. Calc. for C45H42­N8O11Co2: C 54.66, H 4.28, N 11.33%; Found: C 54.58, H 4.31, N 11.32%. CCDC: 1845081 (its crystal data are shown in Table S1 in the SI).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Co-MB

A mixture of 0.0287 g of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O, 0.0165 g of 3,3'-methylenediphthalic acid (H4mda), 0.0270 g of 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)-benzene (bib) (its chemical structure is shown in Figure S1 in the Supporting Information (SI)), and 0.0085 g of sodium hydroxide was dissolved in water (8 mL) in a screw capped vial. The mixture was then placed in an oven at 120 °C for 3 days. Purple crystals with a block shape were obtained after filtration. Yield: 70%. Anal. Calc. for C45H42N8O11Co2: C 54.66, H 4.28, N 11.33%; Found: C 54.58, H 4.31, N 11.32%. CCDC: 1845081 (its crystal data are shown in Table S1 in the SI).

metadata.title:
Cobalt(II)-Based Metal–Organic Framework as
Bifunctional Materials for Ag(I) Detection and Proton Reduction Catalysis
for Hydrogen Production
